title: SRMP tutorials
text:
Preface
Welcome! In these pages you will find tutorial materials for the PPLE Skills and Research Methods for Psychology JASP tutorials. For questions, please mail me

title: 2  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.

1 + 1

[1] 2






Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 2  Summary
text:
In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP
text:
1.1 Learning outcomes
After viewing the tutorial materials and following along with the demonstration, you can:
crumbs: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP

title: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP
text:
Filter data according to certain values of cases (select cases)
Compute new variables from existing variables
Recode existing variables into new variables
Run descriptive statistics and frequencies
crumbs: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP

title: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP
text:
1.2 Datasets
This demonstration uses the dataset ReducedESS11 which you can download here.
The dataset consists of 7 variables:

Country

Belgium, France, Germany, Hungary and the Netherlands

imsmetn (“Allow many/few immigrants of same race/ethnic group as majority”)

“Allow none”
“Allow some”
“Allow a few”
“Allow none”

imdfetn (“Allow many/few immigrants of different race/ethnic group from majority”)

Scale as imsmetn

impcntr (“Allow many/few immigrants from poorer countries outside Europe”)

Scale as imsmetn

imbgeco (“Immigration bad or good for country’s economy”)

Scale from 0 (“Bad for the economy”) to 10 (“Good for the economy”)

imueclt (“Country’s cultural life undermined or enriched by immigrants”)

Scale from 0 (“Cultural life undermined”) to 10 (“Cultural life enriched”)

imwbcnt (“Immigrants make country worse or better place to live”)

Scale from 0 (“Worse place to live”) to 10 (“Better place to live”)
crumbs: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP

title: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP
crumbs: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP

title: 2  Bias and checking assumptions
text:
2.1 Learning outcomes
After viewing the tutorial materials and following along with the demonstration, you can:

title: 2  Bias and checking assumptions
text:
Screen for outliers using the boxplot rule
Check the assumptions of normality and homogeneity of variances, using plots and tests

title: 2  Bias and checking assumptions
text:
2.2 Datasets
This demonstration uses the dataset ReducedESS11 which you can download here. You can see a summary of the variables in the previous tutorial
